title: Kevin Riford's Lawsuit served upon Wheatfield Clerk

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Kevin Riford's Lawsuit served upon Wheatfield Clerk
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of all legal documents served to the Town Cleks Office regarding Kevin Riford v. Rodney Giove.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

The Riford Family

title: Cosmetology programs

communications.subject: Tennessee Public Records Act Request: Cosmetology programs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Tennessee Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1) Pass rates on the state cosmetology licensing exam, broken down by school, between 1/1/2023 to the present

2) Copies of all complaints, from 1/1/2022 through present, regarding the following institutions, inclusive of any and all their campuses:

Tennessee School of Beauty of Knoxville Inc
Paul Mitchell the School
Empire Beauty School
Gould's Academy
TC Beauty
Austin's Beauty College Inc
Genesis Career College-Lebanon
The Hair Academy LLC
Franklin Hair Academy School of Cosmetology
Sandra Academy of Salon Services


If the complaints are too numerous by page and would require a cost estimate, please send me a spreadsheet of the complaints, which includes the complaint information, without the attachments.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Meredith Kolodner

title: Safety National Investigation

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Safety National Investigation
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

all records, correspondence, and supporting documentation related to the California Department of Insurance’s Market Conduct Examination of Safety National Casualty Corporation, as adopted April 30, 2025. This includes but is not limited to: (1) the specific claim files reviewed during the examination (redacted as necessary), (2) internal guidelines or claims procedures submitted by the company, (3) examiner workpapers or notes, (4) correspondence between CDI and Safety National regarding findings or corrective actions, and (5) any corrective action plans, compliance reports, or follow-up monitoring related to the violations cited in the report.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Fecteau

files.source: Matthew Fecteau

To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following California Public Records Act request, copied below, and originally submitted on July 3, 2025. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

communications.subject: RE: PRA-2025-00455 (PY) Req. for All Records, Correspondence, and Supporting Documentation Re. the Market Conduct Examination of Safety National Casualty Corporation (NAIC: 15105, CA: 3605-3)
communications.communication:
Good afternoon, Matthew,

On July 3, 2025, the California Department of Insurance (“Department”) Custodian of Records received your request for information regarding the above-referenced matter, which has been treated as a request pursuant to the California Public Records Act (Gov. Code, § 7920.000 et seq.).

Specifically, your request seeks the following regarding the market conduct exam of Safety National Casualty Corporation (NAIC #: 15105, CA #: 3605-3):


  1.  All records, correspondence, and supporting documentation related to the California Department of Insurance’s Market Conduct Examination of Safety National Casualty Corporation, as adopted April 30, 2025. This includes but is not limited to:
     *   The specific claim files reviewed during the examination (redacted as necessary);
     *   Internal guidelines or claims procedures submitted by the company;
     *   Examiner workpapers or notes;
     *   Correspondence between CDI and Safety National regarding findings or corrective actions; and
     *   Any corrective action plans, compliance reports, or follow-up monitoring related to the violations cited in the report.

After a reasonable search and inquiry, the Department has concluded its search and located responsive records. Please be advised that records pertaining to the specific claim files reviewed during the examination, internal guidelines or claims procedures submitted by the company, examiner workpapers or notes, and correspondence between CDI and the company are confidential and not subject to disclosure under Insurance Code sections 735.5, subdivision (c), and 12919, Evidence Code section 1040, Government Code sections 7927.500, 7929.000, 7922.000, and 7927.705, the official information privilege, and the deliberative process privilege.

Regarding your request #1e, any agreed corrective action plans can be found in the published exam report. Please visit the Department’s public website to access published Market Conduct Exam Reports<https://interactive.web.insurance.ca.gov/apex_extprd/f?p=151:1::::::>.

Sincerely,

David Lopez
Senior Legal Analyst
California Department of Insurance
Legal Branch | Government Law Bureau
300 Capitol Mall, 17th Floor
Sacramento, CA 95814
Office: (916) 492-3115
CA Department of Insurance<https://www.insurance.ca.gov/>

CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE: This communication with its contents may contain confidential and/or legally privileged information. It is solely for the use of the intended recipient(s). Unauthorized interception, review, use or disclosure is prohibited and may violate applicable laws including the Electronic Communications Privacy Act. If you are not the intended recipient, please contact the sender and destroy all copies of the communication.

title: Decertification List

communications.subject: Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Decertification List
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

DCJS's Master Decertification List,  including  but not limited to all pending, final, prior and reinstated police decertification data. 

Data dictionary and documentation 
I also request all documentation that describes the layout of the database’s tables and fields, and that provides the definitions of any field names, codes, and abbreviations used in the database. This information may be gathered together in a single document like a data dictionary, entity layout, or user's guide. If that is the case, I request access to and copy of said document. Should the records above represent certain values as numeric codes or abbreviations that are not self-explanatory, I additionally request all records necessary to interpret those codes and abbreviations.

Data format 
I request these records in their native digital formats and not in formats that degrade the accessibility of the records, such as tabular data converted to PDF or Word files. If converting the native digital format to another high-fidelity format, such as CSV or Excel, please take care not to introduce formatting inconsistencies or errors, which can occur in the conversion process (for example, encoding errors or the inclusion of internal unescaped quotation marks in CSV files).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Tom Nash, a citizen of Virginia, in coordination with Dillon Bergin.

title: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 FOIA Logs (Department of Justice - FOIA/PA Mail Referral Unit)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 FOIA Logs (Department of Justice - FOIA/PA Mail Referral Unit)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of the log of all Freedom of Information Act request made between 2019 and 2025 that includes the term "Title IX" within reference to the Education Amendments of 1972, specifically as they refer to sexual misconduct policy. I ask that all fields — including the subject of the request, the nature and description of the request, the requester, the status of the request, the dates on which it was requested and the date of its most recent status, the tracking number assigned to the request, and the final disposition of the request — be included.

I require this data for academic research purposes, in association with the University of Maryland - College Park. The study aims to understand the recent history of the development of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972, from 2010 to now.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Sarah Silberman

title: Patron Incident Reports - May/June 2025

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Patron Incident Reports - May/June 2025
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

1. All Patron Incident Reports submitted for the Area Manager 5 North Region from May 16, 2025 through June 11, 2025 inclusive of those dates.

2. All Patron Incident Reports submitted systemwide where the fields "Police Called" or "Security Called" are True from May 16, 2025 through June 11, 2025 inclusive of those dates.

Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit Lucy Parsons Labs for the purpose of public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

communications.subject: FOIA 6135 - Patron Incident Reports - May/June 2025
communications.communication:
Thank you for your interest in obtaining information from the Chicago Park District.

Your FOIA reference number for tracking purposes is: 6135

You have requested the following records :

Alexandra Gelzin
MuckRock News
DEPT MR 187939
263 Huntington Ave
Boston, MA 02115

“Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:
1. All Patron Incident Reports submitted for the Area Manager 5 North Region from May 16, 2025 through June 11, 2025 inclusive of those dates.
2. All Patron Incident Reports submitted systemwide where the fields "Police Called" or "Security Called" are True from May 16, 2025 through June 11, 2025 inclusive of those dates.
Because this request is in the public interest for Illinois nonprofit Lucy Parsons Labs for the purpose of public education, please waive any fees in accordance with 5 ILCS § 140/6(c).
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.
Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.”

The Chicago Park District (the “Park District”) responds to all public records requests by the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (FOIA), 5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.  Please expect a response by June 20, 2025 by close of business. Please be advised that the Park District is closed on Thursday June 19, 2025, in observance of the Juneteenth Holiday. If additional time is needed to assemble and copy all documents responsive to your FOIA request, we will contact you with a time estimate and a request to extend.

Thank you,

Kevin Murphy

title: 5 Oldest Requests (National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: 5 Oldest Requests (National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

All records referencing the five oldest FOIA and Privacy Act requests which are still being processed that contain remarks, comments, notes, explanations, etc. made by your personnel or contractors about the processing of these requests (and appeals, if appropriate), the invocation of exemptions, or related matters. This is to include any analysts' notes made during the processing of the requests, any standard worksheets completed by the analysts, any justifications for exemption invocations or other supporting documentation provided to the Appeals Authority, and any correspondence referencing the requests, including tasking orders, emails, and coordination documentation. However, any records previously released to the original requesters in unredacted form may be excluded from this request. Additionally, please provide the initial request letters for the 5 oldest open FOIA/PA requests.

When processing this request, please note that the D.C. Circuit has previously held that agencies have a duty to construe the subject material of FOIA requests liberally to ensure responsive records are not overlooked. See Nation Magazine, Washington Bureau v. U.S. Customs Service, 71 F.3d 885, 890 (D.C. Cir. 1995). Accordingly, you are hereby instructed that the term “record” includes, but is not limited to: 1) all email communications to or from any individual within your agency; 2) memoranda; 3) inter-agency communications; 4) sound recordings; 5) tape recordings; 6) video or film recordings; 7) photographs; 8) notes; 9) notebooks; 10) indices; 11) jottings; 12) message slips; 13) letters or correspondence; 14) telexes; 15) telegrams; 16) facsimile transmissions; 17) statements; 18) policies; 19) manuals or binders; 20) books; 21) handbooks; 22) business records; 23) personnel records; 24) ledgers; 25) notices; 26) warnings; 27) affidavits; 28) declarations under penalty of perjury; 29) unsworn statements; 30) reports; 31) diaries; or 32) calendars, regardless of whether they are handwritten, printed, typed, mechanically or electronically recorded or reproduced on any medium capable of conveying an image, such as paper, CDs, DVDs, or diskettes.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Michael Quinn

title: Automated License Plate Reader (ALPR) Records Request (Palo Alto Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Automated License Plate Reader (ALPR) Records Request (Palo Alto Police Department)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").
Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.
A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shared ALPR data in 2025;
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency received ALPR data in 2025;
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information in 2025;
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information in 2025.
The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function.
Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA.
However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records:
A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy.
A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.
A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods June 5th, 2024 until the date of processing this request.
Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce.
Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)
B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2025.
B2. The aggregate number of “hits” during 2025.
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from June 5th, 2024 until the date this request is processed.  If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days.
B4. The aggregate number of “hits” from June 5th, 2024 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. 
B5. Average Daily Scans based on the past amount of days in which you retain data.
The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.
Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations.
We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act
C1. A description of the information technology and physical location in which the records exist.
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought.
Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a PDF below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records.
(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set)
Part D - Information Related to New Changes
D1. Flock Safety has announced that they are building a product called Flock Nova, which combines information from agencies into one place, such as “Unify CAD, RMS, video, LPR, and public records.” It is mentioned in this article (https://www.404media.co/license-plate-reader-company-flock-is-building-a-massive-people-lookup-tool-leak-shows/) that the tool is being used by some law enforcement agencies in an early access program (https://www.flocksafety.com/devices/flock-nova#:~:text=Flock%20Nova%20Early%20Access%20Now%20Open). Is/was your Agency part of, invited to, or booked a demo for the early access program? Is/has your Agency utilized Flock Nova? If yes, have you used the tool in any police investigations?
D2. Please send a document of the most up-to-date ALPR policy that your Agency uses.
Part E – Information Related to ALPR Camera Locations
E1. The location (address, intersection, coordinates, or nearest landmark) of each ALPR camera operated, maintained, or accessed by the Agency as of the date of this request.
E2. If your agency uses mobile ALPR cameras (e.g., on patrol cars), please indicate how many mobile units are currently deployed, and describe any policies that govern how locations of scans from mobile units are logged or stored.
E3. If exact addresses or coordinates are withheld, please provide general placement descriptions (e.g., "fixed camera at Main St & 2nd Ave," or "mobile ALPR unit assigned to Northern District patrol vehicle").
This information is typically accessible within ALPR system management software. For example:
- In Flock Safety camera location information is visible through the camera dashboard and deployment maps.
- In Vigilant/Motorola, camera locations are often listed in the device management or configuration settings.
Part F - ALPR Vendor Contracts and Purchase Agreements
F1. All contracts, purchase orders, service agreements, statements of work, or memoranda of understanding between the Agency and any vendor of ALPR technology (including Flock Safety, Vigilant Solutions/Motorola, etc.) in effect during January 1, 2024–June 5, 2025. 
F2. All invoices, receipts, and payment records related to the purchase, installation, operation, or maintenance of ALPR systems during January 1, 2024–June 5, 2025. 
F3. Any grant applications or grant award documents (e.g., from DHS, DOJ, or private foundations) that funded or supported the acquisition or expansion of ALPR systems.
Part G – Internal Communications and Rationale for Placement
G1. Any internal memos, emails, reports, or presentations from 2022–2025 discussing where ALPR cameras should be placed or were ultimately placed. This includes communications from officers, command staff, city officials, or vendor representatives regarding:
- Placement location recommendations
- Crime statistics or justifications used to determine placement
- Community concerns or opposition
- Equity or privacy impacts
- “High crime” area designations or related targeting rationale
G2. Any communications with Flock Safety, Vigilant Solutions, or other ALPR vendors from 2022–2025 regarding camera placement, pilot programs, early access programs, or system expansion.
CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records.
We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request.
Part H – ALPR Audit Logs & Access Records (More Detail)
H1. A list of all ALPR database users employed by the Agency between June 5, 2024 and the present, including job titles, divisions, and access levels. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. 
H2. Audit logs showing ALPR database access by Agency personnel from June 5, 2024 to the present. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.  Please include:
1. Organization Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the date above, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.
- Date and time of access
- Name and Job Title of User
- Search parameters (e.g., plate number or geographic query)
- Stated reason for access, if logged
2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period from the date above, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.
These logs are required under California Civil Code § 1798.90.52(a) and can help determine how often ALPR data is being queried and by whom. These records have been disclosed by several agencies in prior CPRA requests.
If the records responsive to any part of this request are held by another department, division, or city office (such as the Mayor’s Office, Department of Technology, SFMTA, or a surveillance oversight board), please identify the appropriate custodian or refer this request accordingly, as required under Government Code § 6253.1.
In particular, if your agency does not maintain records related to:
- The policy rationale or decision-making process for camera placement
- Contracts or procurement related to ALPR vendors
- Surveillance technology policy
Please inform me which department or office may hold these records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Omar Solis

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: R001152-060825
communications.communication:
Dear Omar Solis: 
 
Thank you for your interest in Public Records retained by the Palo Alto Police Department. Your request has been received and is being processed in accordance with California Government Code Sections 6260, et al., the California Public Records Act. Your request was received in this office on 6/8/2025 and given the reference number R001152-060825 for tracking purposes. Records Requested: To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").
Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.
A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shared ALPR data in 2025;
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency received ALPR data in 2025;
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information in 2025;
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information in 2025.
The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function.
Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA.
However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records:
A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy.
A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.
A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods June 5th, 2024 until the date of processing this request.
Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce.
Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)
B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2025.
B2. The aggregate number of “hits” during 2025.
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from June 5th, 2024 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days.
B4. The aggregate number of “hits” from June 5th, 2024 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.
B5. Average Daily Scans based on the past amount of days in which you retain data.
The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.
Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations.
We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act
C1. A description of the information technology and physical location in which the records exist.
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought.
Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a PDF below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records.
(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set)
Part D - Information Related to New Changes
D1. Flock Safety has announced that they are building a product called Flock Nova, which combines information from agencies into one place, such as “Unify CAD, RMS, video, LPR, and public records.” It is mentioned in this article (https://www.404media.co/license-plate-reader-company-flock-is-building-a-massive-people-lookup-tool-leak-shows/) that the tool is being used by some law enforcement agencies in an early access program (https://www.flocksafety.com/devices/flock-nova#:~:text=Flock%20Nova%20Early%20Access%20Now%20Open). Is/was your Agency part of, invited to, or booked a demo for the early access program? Is/has your Agency utilized Flock Nova? If yes, have you used the tool in any police investigations?
D2. Please send a document of the most up-to-date ALPR policy that your Agency uses.
Part E – Information Related to ALPR Camera Locations
E1. The location (address, intersection, coordinates, or nearest landmark) of each ALPR camera operated, maintained, or accessed by the Agency as of the date of this request.
E2. If your agency uses mobile ALPR cameras (e.g., on patrol cars), please indicate how many mobile units are currently deployed, and describe any policies that govern how locations of scans from mobile units are logged or stored.
E3. If exact addresses or coordinates are withheld, please provide general placement descriptions (e.g., "fixed camera at Main St & 2nd Ave," or "mobile ALPR unit assigned to Northern District patrol vehicle").
This information is typically accessible within ALPR system management software. For example:
- In Flock Safety camera location information is visible through the camera dashboard and deployment maps.
- In Vigilant/Motorola, camera locations are often listed in the device management or configuration settings.
Part F - ALPR Vendor Contracts and Purchase Agreements
F1. All contracts, purchase orders, service agreements, statements of work, or memoranda of understanding between the Agency and any vendor of ALPR technology (including Flock Safety, Vigilant Solutions/Motorola, etc.) in effect during January 1, 2024–June 5, 2025.
F2. All invoices, receipts, and payment records related to the purchase, installation, operation, or maintenance of ALPR systems during January 1, 2024–June 5, 2025.
F3. Any grant applications or grant award documents (e.g., from DHS, DOJ, or private foundations) that funded or supported the acquisition or expansion of ALPR systems.
Part G – Internal Communications and Rationale for Placement
G1. Any internal memos, emails, reports, or presentations from 2022–2025 discussing where ALPR cameras should be placed or were ultimately placed. This includes communications from officers, command staff, city officials, or vendor representatives regarding:
- Placement location recommendations
- Crime statistics or justifications used to determine placement
- Community concerns or opposition
- Equity or privacy impacts
- “High crime” area designations or related targeting rationale
G2. Any communications with Flock Safety, Vigilant Solutions, or other ALPR vendors from 2022–2025 regarding camera placement, pilot programs, early access programs, or system expansion.
CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records.
We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request.
Part H – ALPR Audit Logs & Access Records (More Detail)
H1. A list of all ALPR database users employed by the Agency between June 5, 2024 and the present, including job titles, divisions, and access levels. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.
H2. Audit logs showing ALPR database access by Agency personnel from June 5, 2024 to the present. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. Please include:
1. Organization Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the date above, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency.
- Date and time of access
- Name and Job Title of User
- Search parameters (e.g., plate number or geographic query)
- Stated reason for access, if logged
2. Network Audit in Flock.
The report should include data logged from the period from the date above, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System.
These logs are required under California Civil Code § 1798.90.52(a) and can help determine how often ALPR data is being queried and by whom. These records have been disclosed by several agencies in prior CPRA requests.
If the records responsive to any part of this request are held by another department, division, or city office (such as the Mayor’s Office, Department of Technology, SFMTA, or a surveillance oversight board), please identify the appropriate custodian or refer this request accordingly, as required under Government Code § 6253.1.
In particular, if your agency does not maintain records related to:
- The policy rationale or decision-making process for camera placement
- Contracts or procurement related to ALPR vendors
- Surveillance technology policy
Please inform me which department or office may hold these records.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Omar Solis

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fpalo-alto-police-department-404%252Fautomated-license-plate-reader-alpr-records-request-palo-alto-police-department-187608%252F%253Femail%253Ddacia.tavares%252540cityofpaloalto.org&url_auth_token=AAAdGkZVM5s1T3Gc4G57-xbCdMY%3A1uOTGf%3AMHiAG5Kflu9sRJq6DRHFsAwcXdB5vDGzSINlfbiW5ck 
Your request will be forwarded to the relevant department(s) to locate the information you seek and to determine the volume and any costs associated with satisfying your request. You will be contacted about the availability and/or provided with copies of the records in question. 
 
PLEASE NOTE: The California Public Records Act, CPRA does not require a governmental body to create new information, to do legal research, or to answer questions. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. 
 
Again, thank you for using the Public Records Center. 
Palo Alto Police Department

Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 
Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist) 
B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2025. 
B2. The aggregate number of “hits” during 2025. 
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from June 5th, 2024 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days. 
B4. The aggregate number of “hits” from June 5th, 2024 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. 
B5. Average Daily Scans based on the past amount of days in which you retain data. 
The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software. 
Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations. 
We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act 
C1. A description of the information technology and physical location in which the records exist. 
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and 
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought. 
Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a PDF below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records. 
(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set) 
Part D - Information Related to New Changes 
D1. Flock Safety has announced that they are building a product called Flock Nova, which combines information from agencies into one place, such as “Unify CAD, RMS, video, LPR, and public records.” It is mentioned in this article (https://www.404media.co/license-plate-reader-company-flock-is-building-a-massive-people-lookup-tool-leak-shows/) that the tool is being used by some law enforcement agencies in an early access program (https://www.flocksafety.com/devices/flock-nova#:~:text=Flock%20Nova%20Early%20Access%20Now%20Open). Is/was your Agency part of, invited to, or booked a demo for the early access program? Is/has your Agency utilized Flock Nova? If yes, have you used the tool in any police investigations? 
D2. Please send a document of the most up-to-date ALPR policy that your Agency uses. 
Part E – Information Related to ALPR Camera Locations 
E1. The location (address, intersection, coordinates, or nearest landmark) of each ALPR camera operated, maintained, or accessed by the Agency as of the date of this request. 
E2. If your agency uses mobile ALPR cameras (e.g., on patrol cars), please indicate how many mobile units are currently deployed, and describe any policies that govern how locations of scans from mobile units are logged or stored. 
E3. If exact addresses or coordinates are withheld, please provide general placement descriptions (e.g., "fixed camera at Main St & 2nd Ave," or "mobile ALPR unit assigned to Northern District patrol vehicle"). 
This information is typically accessible within ALPR system management software. For example: 
- In Flock Safety camera location information is visible through the camera dashboard and deployment maps. 
- In Vigilant/Motorola, camera locations are often listed in the device management or configuration settings. 
Part F - ALPR Vendor Contracts and Purchase Agreements 
F1. All contracts, purchase orders, service agreements, statements of work, or memoranda of understanding between the Agency and any vendor of ALPR technology (including Flock Safety, Vigilant Solutions/Motorola, etc.) in effect during January 1, 2024–June 5, 2025. 
F2. All invoices, receipts, and payment records related to the purchase, installation, operation, or maintenance of ALPR systems during January 1, 2024–June 5, 2025. 
F3. Any grant applications or grant award documents (e.g., from DHS, DOJ, or private foundations) that funded or supported the acquisition or expansion of ALPR systems. 
Part G – Internal Communications and Rationale for Placement 
G1. Any internal memos, emails, reports, or presentations from 2022–2025 discussing where ALPR cameras should be placed or were ultimately placed. This includes communications from officers, command staff, city officials, or vendor representatives regarding: 
- Placement location recommendations 
- Crime statistics or justifications used to determine placement 
- Community concerns or opposition 
- Equity or privacy impacts 
- “High crime” area designations or related targeting rationale 
G2. Any communications with Flock Safety, Vigilant Solutions, or other ALPR vendors from 2022–2025 regarding camera placement, pilot programs, early access programs, or system expansion. 
CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 
We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 
Part H – ALPR Audit Logs & Access Records (More Detail) 
H1. A list of all ALPR database users employed by the Agency between June 5, 2024 and the present, including job titles, divisions, and access levels. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. 
H2. Audit logs showing ALPR database access by Agency personnel from June 5, 2024 to the present. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. Please include: 
1. Organization Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the date above, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done within the agency. 
- Date and time of access 
- Name and Job Title of User 
- Search parameters (e.g., plate number or geographic query) 
- Stated reason for access, if logged 
2. Network Audit in Flock. 
The report should include data logged from the period from the date above, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the organization’s Flock network by any agency in the Flock System. 
These logs are required under California Civil Code § 1798.90.52(a) and can help determine how often ALPR data is being queried and by whom. These records have been disclosed by several agencies in prior CPRA requests. 
If the records responsive to any part of this request are held by another department, division, or city office (such as the Mayor’s Office, Department of Technology, SFMTA, or a surveillance oversight board), please identify the appropriate custodian or refer this request accordingly, as required under Government Code § 6253.1. 
In particular, if your agency does not maintain records related to: 
- The policy rationale or decision-making process for camera placement 
- Contracts or procurement related to ALPR vendors 
- Surveillance technology policy 
Please inform me which department or office may hold these records. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires. 

Sincerely, 

Omar Solis 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fpalo-alto-police-department-404%252Fautomated-license-plate-reader-alpr-records-request-palo-alto-police-department-187608%252F%253Femail%253Ddacia.tavares%252540cityofpaloalto.org&url_auth_token=AAAdGkZVM5s1T3Gc4G57-xbCdMY%3A1uOTGf%3AMHiAG5Kflu9sRJq6DRHFsAwcXdB5vDGzSINlfbiW5ck” 
The Palo Alto Police Department has reviewed its files and has located responsive records to your request. Links that address responses to A1-4, B1-4, A5-7, F3 and G-1/G2 are here: 
https://transparency.flocksafety.com/palo-alto-ca-pd 
https://www.paloalto.gov/Departments/Police/Public-Information-Portal/Automated-License-Plate-Recognition-ALPR 
https://www.paloalto.gov/News-Articles/Police-Department/Police-Receive-State-Grant-for-5M-to-Combat-Organized-Retail-Theft#:~:text=You%20Are%20Here%20:%20Home%20/%20Police,vehicles%20while%20committing%20their%20crimes. 
https://www.cityofpaloalto.org/files/assets/public/v/1/administrative-services/budget-adjustments-and-monitoring/fy-2024-budget-adjustments/december/december-4th-ccm-item-4-staff-report.pdf 
Regarding D1, PAPD was not invited to participate in the Flock Nova program. 
Regarding E2, PAPD only has fixed cameras; no functional car-mounted APLR. 
Regarding E1/E3, Camera location information is exempt from the (CPRA) pursuant to Cal. Gov. § 7923.600. 
Regarding F3, PAPD was able to obtain 10 additional cameras from the ORT Grant (link above) 
Regarding G1/G2, please see links to the staff report, PAPD Website and community presentation that articulates the Departments philosophy on location selection. 
Please log in to the Public Records Center at the following LINK to retrieve the appropriate responsive documents. 
Regards, 

Lisa Scheff 
Public Safety Program Manager/Records | Police Department

title: Record retention schedule and forms (California State Athletic Commission)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Record retention schedule and forms (California State Athletic Commission)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

- all record retention schedules
- master list of forms

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Chris Amico

To Whom It May Concern:

title: E & A Occupancy + Fire Sprinkler Information (Town Of Flower Mound)

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: E & A Occupancy + Fire Sprinkler Information (Town Of Flower Mound)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

I respectfully request an electronic, parcel-level extract containing current Group E (Educational) and Group A (Assembly) occupancies and associated fire-sprinkler information for all parcels within the jurisdiction: 

Please provide one CSV with the following columns (your native field names are fine):
- Parcel identifier (APN / PIN / BBL)
• Site address (street #, street, city, ZIP)
• Latitude & longitude
• Internal building / permit ID
• Year built
• Floor area (sq ft)
• Number of stories
• Current IBC occupancy code (E, A-1…A-5)
• Occupancy description
• Fire-sprinkler present (Yes / No / Unknown)
• Date of last fire-sprinkler inspection (if tracked)
• Owner name & mailing address (if stored)

If any field is not maintained, please note that rather than withholding the entire record.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

David Cavise

title: Organized Retail Crime Task Force: Auror

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Organized Retail Crime Task Force: Auror
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records related to the Organized Retail Crime Theft Task Force announced on June 23, 2022, specifically concerning the implementation, use, and discussion of Auror's crime intelligence platform.

1. All contracts, MOUs, RFPs, or service agreements between the AG's Office and Auror Inc. (auror.co) dated June 23, 2022, to present
1a. Amendments, scope-of-work documents, or SLA agreements related to Auror's services
1b. Invoices, payment receipts, or procurement documents for Auror software/services

2. Budget allocations specific to Auror platform implementation
2a. Documentation of federal/state grants used to fund Auror-related expenditures

3. Training manuals, guides, or protocols for Auror platform use by task force members
3a. Video recordings of Auror software training sessions
3b. Email communications regarding training schedules or materials

4. All incident reports, intelligence briefings, or case files generated through Auror's platform
4a. Spreadsheets/databases tracking organized retail crime incidents processed via Auror
4b. Performance metrics/reports evaluating Auror's effectiveness (2022-2024)

5. Records of technical malfunctions, data inaccuracies, or security breaches involving Auror
5a. Formal complaints from task force members or partner agencies about Auror's system
5b. Internal audits or third-party assessments of Auror's compliance with state data laws

6. Emails/memos between AG staff and Auror representatives (June 23, 2022-present)
6a. Meeting minutes where Auror platform use was discussed
6b. Correspondence with federal partners (FBI, DHS) regarding Auror data sharing

These records are requested from June 23, 2022, to present; Electronic copies are preferred in their original formats wherever possible, and commonly readable formats such as pdf, mp4, png where conversion is required.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Robin Monks

communications.subject: Acknowledgement of Public Records Request - Monks - PRR-2025-0182
communications.communication:
Dear Robin Monks, This correspondence is to acknowledge your public records request received in our office on February 27, 2025. We assigned the file number above to your request. Please reference that number on any future correspondence regarding this request. You requested the following: Records related to the Organized Retail Crime Theft Task Force announced on June 23, 2022, specifically concerning the implementation, use, and discussion of Auror's crime intelligence platform. 
1. All contracts, MOUs, RFPs, or service agreements between the AG's Office and Auror Inc. (auror.co) dated June 23, 2022, to present 
1a. Amendments, scope-of-work documents, or SLA agreements related to Auror's services 
1b. Invoices, payment receipts, or procurement documents for Auror software/services 
2. Budget allocations specific to Auror platform implementation 
2a. Documentation of federal/state grants used to fund Auror-related expenditures 
3. Training manuals, guides, or protocols for Auror platform use by task force members 
3a. Video recordings of Auror software training sessions 
3b. Email communications regarding training schedules or materials 
4. All incident reports, intelligence briefings, or case files generated through Auror's platform 
4a. Spreadsheets/databases tracking organized retail crime incidents processed via Auror 
4b. Performance metrics/reports evaluating Auror's effectiveness (2022-2024) 
5. Records of technical malfunctions, data inaccuracies, or security breaches involving Auror 
5a. Formal complaints from task force members or partner agencies about Auror's system 
5b. Internal audits or third-party assessments of Auror's compliance with state data laws 
6. Emails/memos between AG staff and Auror representatives (June 23, 2022-present) 
6a. Meeting minutes where Auror platform use was discussed 
6b. Correspondence with federal partners (FBI, DHS) regarding Auror data sharing 
These records are requested from June 23, 2022, to present; Electronic copies are preferred in their original formats wherever possible, and commonly readable formats such as pdf, mp4, png where conversion is required. 
The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 
In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. We are searching our records to determine the location, nature, and amount of records, if any, that may be responsive to your request. If responsive records are found, I estimate I can make available an installment of records on or before April 2, 2025. If records are ready prior to that time, I will notify you. If this time assessment requires adjustment, I will also advise you of that. Please contact me within 30 days via email or at Office of the Attorney General, Public Records & Constituent Services, P.O. Box 40100, Olympia, WA 98504-0100, if you have any questions. Thank you. 
 Kristin Young

4a. Spreadsheets/databases tracking organized retail crime incidents processed via Auror 
4b. Performance metrics/reports evaluating Auror's effectiveness (2022-2024)” Clarification Question: When you ask for “incident reports” are you requesting the numerous individual reports written in Auror documenting each alleged criminal act that occurred at the retail establishment (e.g. each report when an individual stole something from a store)? Robin

You requested the following: Records related to the Organized Retail Crime Theft Task Force announced on June 23, 2022, specifically concerning the implementation, use, and discussion of Auror's crime intelligence platform.

communications.subject: FOIA - FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS WITH CURRENT LICENSE
communications.communication:
Good afternoon~

In accordance with the Act, I am providing you the links to Washtenaw County's written FOIA Policy and related information relative to the Freedom of Information Act.   This information is available at https://www.washtenaw.org/DocumentCenter/View/3976/Washtenaw-County-Procedure-for-Freedom-of-Information-Act-FOIA-PDF
If you disagree with this decision or the fees, you may submit a written appeal specifically stating "appeal" and stating the reasons for appeal, to the County Administrator or seek judicial review under Section 10 of the Act within 180 days after the County's final determination.  Within ten (10) days of receiving a request for an appeal, the County Administrator shall (a) reverse the denial; (b) issue a written notice upholding the denial; (c) reverse in part and uphold in part by written notice; or (d) issue a notice extending by ten (10) business days the time to decide the appeal.
If after judicial review, the Circuit Court determines that the County has not fully complied with the disclosure requirements, the Court shall award reasonable attorneys' fees, costs and disbursements.  If the Court determines that the County has arbitrarily and capriciously violated the Act, it will also award punitive damages of $1,000.00.

A copy of this request will be kept on file for no less than one (1) year.


Tanganika Hargrove, MBA
Building Inspection & Environmental Health Administrative Supervisor
Washtenaw County Building Inspection & Environmental Health
705 N. Zeeb Rd.
Ann Arbor, MI 48105
734-222-3864

title: Untitled (Department of Veterans Affairs, Veterans Benefits Administration)

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Untitled (Department of Veterans Affairs, Veterans Benefits Administration)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

This request applies broadly to all contractors utilized by VA to perform disability medical examinations, including but not limited to Veterans Evaluation Services (VES), QTC Medical Services, Logistics Health Incorporated (LHI), and any other contractor or subcontractor operating under VA authority for this purpose.

For the period FY2023 to the present, I request the following records:

List of Contractors: A list of all entities contracted to perform C&P examinations, including contract numbers, effective dates, and scope of services.

Total Contractor Payments: Annual dollar amounts paid to each contractor during the specified period, broken down by fiscal year.

Cost per Examination:

Any documentation showing average cost per examination, broken down by type of exam (e.g., general medical, mental health, musculoskeletal, TBI, Gulf War, audiology, etc.).

Any cost matrix or price schedule showing negotiated or standard rates paid per exam type under each contract.

Any documentation explaining pricing adjustments for travel, expedited scheduling, or exam revisions.

Payment Policies for Inadequate Exams:

Any contract provisions, policy guidance, or internal memos addressing whether and when VA pays contractors for examinations that are later deemed inadequate, noncompliant, or returned for correction.

Documentation clarifying whether such exams are subject to reimbursement, penalty, or payment denial under contract terms.

Quality Assurance and Oversight:

Internal audit reports, performance evaluations, or compliance reviews of contracted C&P examinations.

Records showing error rates, rates of returned exams, or other quality control metrics used to assess contractor performance.

Any internal guidance or SOPs related to the review, correction, or rejection of contractor exams.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Gary

title: Public Records Request - Troop A - Camera Footage - Pursuit and Arrest of Heaven Brander (5/25/24)

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Public Records Request - Troop A - Camera Footage - Pursuit and Arrest of Heaven Brander (5/25/24)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern,

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I am requesting the following records from the Florida Highway Patrol regarding an incident that occurred in the early morning hours of May 25, 2024:

All dash camera footage and any other in-vehicle mounted video recorded during the pursuit of a dark-colored SUV bearing Florida license plate AM16ST, which began in Santa Rosa County around 2:58 AM and continued into Escambia County, Florida.

All  and body-worn camera footage from the officers involved with the subsequent arrest of Heaven Brander, who was the driver of the SUV at the time.

Records authored by Trooper K.A. Davis, who was involved in the stop and created Report #: FHP99ARR68556 and/or Case #: FHP24ON0262026 / RCC24IN0400933.

The subject of this incident was later identified as Heaven Narie Brander (DOB: 10/26/2005), who was transported to Sacred Heart Hospital following the crash and later booked into the Santa Rosa County Jail. The report references dashcam footage as being available at the time of the report.

Please inform me of any potential costs prior to fulfilling this request. I would prefer the records in digital/electronic format, if available.

If this request is too broad or if further clarification is needed, I would be happy to narrow the scope.

Thank you for your time and attention.

title: Wyoming County Excited Delirium Training Materials

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Wyoming County Excited Delirium Training Materials
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all training materials used in the past four years (January 1, 2020 through January 1, 2024) that mention excited delirium / agitated delirium / bell's mania / lethal catatonia.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jenny Wadhwa

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

I wanted to follow up on the following New York Freedom of Information Law request, copied below, and originally submitted on Oct. 25, 2024. Please let me know when I can expect to receive a response.

Thanks for your help, and let me know if further clarification is needed.

Jenny,

I received this FOIL two days ago, and logging into this system it appears you have been trying to submit this for some time.  I apologize for any delay.  I have completed this request and attached relevant documents.  These are slides from our Use of Force annual in-service training program.  "Excited Delirium" is mentioned on only one slide, so I provided you with ten of the slides to provide you  with some context regarding its mention.  Our agency has no specific training program regarding "Excited Delirium", and we have not had any specific training on the condition.  Please reach out directly to me with anything further you may need by email at creagan@wyomingcountyny.gov.  Thank you.

Colin Reagan
Wyoming County Undersheriff

communications.communication:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

The arrest was handled by Officer Shanovia Dove (CCN: PD1279) of the Coral Springs Police Department.

The charges associated with the arrest include:

DUI (Second Offense)

Leaving the Scene of an Accident
Driving While License Suspended

To reduce cost I’d like to narrow the request to:

• No transport, jail/booking, or other officers’ footage

Please send a revised estimate or let me know if you need anything else.

Thanks for your time,
Mich

Thank you.

________________________________

The City of Coral Springs is a public entity subject to Chapter 119 of the Florida Statutes concerning public records. Email messages are covered under Chapter 119 and are thus subject to public records disclosure. All email messages sent and received are captured by our server and retained as public records. This footnote also confirms that this email message has been swept for the presence of computer viruses, and illegal or questionable content. This system is a private system and is monitored for electronic tampering. Violators will be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law. This email may contain confidential or privileged material. title: Policy Documents

communications.subject: Pennsylvania Right to Know Act Request: Policy Documents
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Pennsylvania Right to Know Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any policy manual, employee procedure manual, or folder of collected policies which guide police operations. This may be one document with many policies, or all policies collected.

The original format of the documents is acceptable (PDF, .doc, .txt, etc).

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jesse Wozniak

Hello Jesse,
I have just recently started working with the Borough of Wilkinsburg as the Assistant Borough Manager and Agency Open Records Officer. 
Your RTK request only came across my desk this morning 08/08/2025. I am working to get you the documents requested in under 5 days from receipt this morning. As such, I have set an estimated completion date of 08/13/2025. 
Thank you for your patience as I work to get you a response. 
Be well,
Sergio E. Ruiz
Assistant Borough Manager
Borough of Wilkinsburg

Good morning, Jesse,
Your RTK request has no attached RTKL Request Form. The Borough of Wilkinsburg presently requires an official RTKL form for fulfilling and tracking Right-to-Know requests. This form, available on our website and the OOR site, is also attached to this message. Please complete and return for your request to be fulfilled. Failure to respond by 08/15/2025 COB will result in a closure of this RTK request.
Best,
Sergio E. Ruiz
Assistant Borough Manager
Borough of Wilkinsburg

communications.subject: Louisiana Public Records Law Request: Safety National Policy
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Louisiana Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

A copy of Safety National Policy GL 6676132 and CA 6676131, and any disclaimers or partial disclaimers sent out to the city from January 1st 2024 until the processing of this request.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Fecteau

title: Amtrak Board of Directors - Meeting  Minutes | Oct 2024

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Amtrak Board of Directors - Meeting  Minutes | Oct 2024
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The minutes for any meeting of the Amtrak Board of Directors that occurred in the month of October 2024, including the minutes for meetings on October 22, 2024 and October 25, 2024 that were approved at the board meeting on January 29, 2025.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Ben Heckscher

I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter.
